content: The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" is the short title of the Act. It includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with a method for making these adjustments. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes adjustments to individual income tax rates based on regional cost-of-living, with specific multipliers applied to rate brackets in the statistical area where the individual resides. The tax rates for each bracket are adjusted accordingly without changing the bracket itself. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 adjusts individual income tax rates based on regional cost-of-living by applying specific multipliers to rate brackets in the statistical area where the individual resides. The tax rates for each bracket are adjusted without changing the bracket itself, and the Secretary determines applicable multipliers for each statistical area annually. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 adjusts individual income tax rates based on regional cost-of-living by applying specific multipliers to rate brackets in the statistical area where the individual resides. The Secretary determines applicable multipliers annually, with different percentages based on cost-of-living differentials in each statistical area. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 adjusts individual income tax rates based on regional cost-of-living differentials by applying specific multipliers to rate brackets in statistical areas. The cost-of-living differential for any statistical area in a calendar year is determined by dividing the area's cost-of-living by the average cost-of-living. The applicable multiplier varies based on the percentage of the cost-of-living differential, with specific values outlined for different scenarios. The cost-of-living index for statistical areas is determined by dividing the area's cost-of-living by the average cost-of-living for the United States. The Secretary of Labor calculates and publishes the cost-of-living index based on market prices for each area annually. The cost-of-living index for statistical areas is based on average market prices for the area for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of each calendar year, using the same methodology as the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers. The amendment defines a statistical area as a metropolitan statistical area or the portion of a state not within one. The applicable multiplier for areas outside the United States is 1. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009.
